I agree with much of what @bh4eh and @benjuliano1 remarked in their posts. The fact that the question presents the possibility of these "forces" being militia and law enforcement raises the probability that a lethal confrontation could occur, both because it is a larger class of actors than exclusively military forces but also because China has used their LE forces heavily in the the South China Seas. Here's a great visual reference on the use of LE in maritime disputes in the SCS since 2010 (note that this does not show disputes relative to military forces) to demonstrate when, how, where and resolution of these disputes: https://csis-ilab.github.io/cpower-viz/csis-china-sea/ Note that India is not listed in any of the maritime disputes in the SCS, which tend to revolve around territorial/sea claims. Nevertheless, China shows it routinely uses ramming, harassment, arrest, official protest, shooting, water cannon, and has detained foreign individuals for alleged activities that violate Chinese sovereignty--all activities that could quickly escalate in a situation where China perceived India was in unauthorized sea territory. I am not confident that losing an individual or two during a detainment or arrest would make it into the press, either.  China is active in the Indian Ocean at a rate of approx 7-8 warships at any given time, so there is also an opportunity for confrontation there as well, albeit limited. It is interesting to consider how China might escalate in defending its encroachments into India's EEZ waters. I think this is a more interesting question and actually an important indicator of the extent China intends to make claims well outside its immediate territory but within the region. I will be on the lookout for any changes in Chinese posture when challenged by Indian naval forces or LE to leave India's EEZ waters, both as an indicator of longer-term Chinese regional intentions and to change this forecast. If China starts to challenge India's direction to leave their EEZ waters, I will increase my forecast probability here.  India has been very vocal about the SCS being part of international waters and free to navigate for all this year, expressing the intent to conduct freedom-of-navigation ops in the SCS, as of mid-year 2020. It is unclear if these FON ops have commenced. Overall, it seems that despite India's vocalness on this issue, there is presently a pretty low opportunity for conflict in the SCS for their forces. Given that India's joint summit with ASEAN this month focused on the importance of continued exercise of FON in the "vital sea lane" in the SCS: http://www.ecoti.in/Qdvtpb96 and 30% of their total trade transits the SCS (https://chinapower.csis.org/much-trade-transits-south-china-sea/), I expect this to remain a big issue for them through 2021. If India were to commence FON operations in the SCS, to conduct a FON exercise in the SCS, or to escort any of its trade carriers, I'd increase my forecast.  My inside view on this is that China could flex some coercive muscle in the early 2021 timeframe when the US is focused on the peaceful transition of power domestically, both to reassert dominance vis-a-vis India, to 'punish' them for the June 2020 border skirmish and also for dropping out of the RCEP. Wouldn't it be nice for China to get India to accede to the regional power hierarchy sooner rather than later?  In sum,
1. low base rate, as established by @benjuliano1(extrapolating roughly from that base rate logic, gives me 13.7% probability from today up to March 1, 2021)
2. relatively high tension period, with deadly land conflict in June 2020
3. increased probability of rising Indian forces activity in SCS, creating more opportunity for forces to come into contact
4. fleeting opportunity for the US to be obsessively focused on domestic power transition

The base rate for naval confrontations in the 21st century is one every 674.7 days. Extrapolating that out we would expect the next one to occur around April 2022. That doesn’t mean that the battle would be lethal. Roughly 40 to 60 percent of naval confrontations in the past two decades have been lethal. [1]. Our logical so far tells us that a naval standoff is not likely before the stated day of 1 March 2021. With that in mind, let’s add some detail from the Sino-Indian situation addressed in the question. I won’t go into detail about the Sino-India border conflict but we know that in its 80-year history both sides have shown a strong preference for engagement on land rather than at sea. There are historical reasons for this which make it a weaker precedent than in other cases. Both China and India have industrialized rapidly over the past three decades. China has invested heavily in its naval capabilities. In its report on the subject to Congress released early this month, the Department of Defense noted “China has already achieved parity with—or even exceeded—the United States in several military modernization areas”. [2] We should note this however in the context of the People’s Liberation Army’s wider strategy and mandate. “China’s leaders use tactics short of armed conflict to pursue China’s objectives. China calibrates its coercive activities to fall below the threshold of provoking armed conflict with the United States, its allies and partners, or others in the Indo-Pacific region,” say the top brass. [3]  On the other hand, China will not miss an opportunity to project its power and views sea assets as critical to that mission given the strategic importance that both countries place on their proximity to major trade thoroughfares in the South China Sea and Indian Ocean respectively. The so-called ‘String of Pearls’ is evidence that China is preparing for a massive sea-based mobilization against India. Of course, no such action is inevitable but it is credible to posit that the Chinese see wisdom in preparing for a transition from land-based confrontation. Up to this point all five major incidents have occurred in the border regions. [5] Here’s how I see these pieces fitting together.  1.	We have a low base rate. 153 days until 1 March divided by 674 days average time between generic naval confrontations yields a 23.7 percent chance of some kind of generic naval event.
2.	We are at the highest tension point between the two powers in 50 years. A conflict that has been historically land-based but shows signs of spilling over to high seas although when that will happen, we can’t be sure. [6]
3.	Just because there is a confrontation doesn’t necessarily mean it will be lethal. Reducing it by half seems deep given the rising tension so a 25 percent might be a better figure. Final judgement, if there is a confrontation it is more likely to be land-based. Naval clashes are an increasing, albeit remote possibility. 18 percent. Comments welcome. And recent diplomatic talks (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-54113621) seem to have lessened tensions to some degree.  Miscalculation and escalation are always a risk, but I expect cooler heads to prevail.
